1582577947_1DnpB2yFpVwyhA29h2rRsifGVEC1s.body:
The way I see it right now with maybe the exception of china, panic causes more problems than the actual virus itself.
The masses get scared very easily and the msm and social media amplify that panic several times more!
If a truly deadly plague happens at some point we will probably be doomed long before the disease kill us only because of the effects of mass panic.
Even if you don't panic yourself if a large enough amount of the population get scared you will feel the effects sooner or later so probably you should get prepared for that.
Imo the bigger problem is that most people in the world are poor so they can't afford to properly prepare for an extended period of time, most people will die just because they didn't have the resources to prepare themselves in the first place.
I think this corona virus showed us our vulnerabilities and if we don't do something to fix them next time probably we will not be so lucky.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_1883_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): panic 'is good for morons':it exterminates 'some of them'.

The problem is that it can exterminate the non-morons too with the same ease...

1581933903_14dsVvztuXjBxWmk4s4HjUnxuN4Ae.body:
Imo if you genuinely have fun your time is not wasted.  
The only reason that games are addictive nowadays is because of greed, big companies want to make all the money with the smallest investment, they don't care about making good fun games nowadays only money.  

So the easiest way to keep getting money with the least amount of investment is to make them as a "service", addictive and with sneaky ways to get money out of your wallet for example login rewards are a way to keep you playing even a little bit every day, virtual coins or money or gems or whatever that you buy for real money are made so that you don't realize how much real money you actually spent in-game. 

Also they really like to prey on the vulnerable people and kids with a bunch of different gambling mechanics, they know and intentionally create their gambling, microtransaction and gameplay mechanics so that it appeals to kids and vulnerable people so they get hooked and then they can't help it but waste a ton of time and money into those "games".

Thankfully there are still some smaller companies that still make good fun games without all the bullshit but they becoming fewer every year. Many of these smaller companies either can't afford to continue and close or they are forced to go the direction of the major game companies or even worse get bought by these major companies, the ones that still manage to keep making good games and good profit are very very few.

I hope in the near future the direction of the gaming industry gets turned around but I doubt it...
